factoid: Rostóv thought "And I might have been in his place!".
Rostóv felt pity for the Emperor and rode on in utter despair.
Rostóv did not know where or why he was now riding.
Rostóv felt his own weakness caused his grief.
Rostóv could have gone up to the sovereign to show devotion to the Emperor.
Rostóv had not made use of the opportunity to show devotion to the Emperor.
Rostóv thought "What have I done?".
Rostóv turned round and galloped back to the place where he had seen the Emperor.
The Emperor was not present beyond the ditch at that time.
Only carts and carriages were passing by the ditch.
A driver informed Rostóv that Kutúzov’s staff were not far off, in the village the vehicles were going to.
Rostóv followed the staff.
A groom walked in front of Rostóv, leading horses in horsecloths.
A cart followed the groom.
An old bandy-legged domestic serf walked behind the cart, wearing a peaked cap and sheepskin coat.
The groom said "Tit! I say, Tit!".
The old man answered "What?" absent-mindedly.
The groom said "Go, Tit! Thresh a bit!".
The old man said "Oh, you fool!" and spat angrily.
The same joke was repeated after some silence.
Before five in the evening the battle had been lost at all points.
More than a hundred cannon were already in the hands of the French.
Przebyszéwski and his corps had laid down their arms.
Other columns, after losing half their men, were retreating in disorderly confused masses.
The remains of Langeron’s and Dokhtúrov’s mingled forces were crowding around the dams and banks of the ponds near the village of Augesd.

After five o’clock it was only at the Augesd Dam that a hot cannonade delivered by the French alone was still to be heard from numerous batteries ranged on the slopes of the Pratzen Heights, directed at the retreating forces.
In the rearguard, Dokhtúrov and others rallying some battalions kept up a musketry fire at the French cavalry that was pursuing the troops.
It was growing dusk.
On the narrow Augesd Dam, the old miller had been accustomed to sit in his tasseled cap peacefully angling.
The old miller's grandson handled floundering silvery fish in a watering can.
On that dam, Moravians in shaggy caps and blue jackets had peacefully driven their two-horse carts loaded with wheat and had returned dusty with flour whitening their carts.

Men disfigured by fear of death crowded together on the dam, crushing one another, dying, stepping over the dying and killing one another, only to move on a few steps and be killed themselves in the same way.
Every ten seconds a cannon ball flew compressing the air around.
A shell burst in the midst of that dense throng, killing some and splashing with blood those near them.
Dólokhov, now an officer, was wounded in the arm and on foot, with the regimental commander on horseback and some ten men of his company, represented all that was left of that whole regiment.
The crowd was wedged in at the approach to the dam and jammed in on all sides, stopped because a horse in front had fallen under a cannon and the crowd were dragging the fallen horse out.
A cannon ball killed someone behind them, another fell in front and splashed Dólokhov with blood.
The crowd pushed forward desperately, squeezed together, moved a few steps, and again stopped.
Each one thought "Move on a hundred yards and we are certainly saved, remain here another two minutes and it is certain death.".
Dólokhov, in the midst of the crowd, forced his way to the edge of the dam, throwing two soldiers off their feet, and ran onto the slippery ice that covered the millpool.
Dólokhov shouted "Turn this way!" while jumping over the ice which creaked under him.
Dólokhov shouted "Turn this way!" to those with the gun.
Dólokhov shouted "It bears!".
